case_vignette: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric psychologist by his mother because of poor academic performance. The patient’s mother mentions that his academic performance was excellent in kindergarten and first grade, but his second and third-grade teachers complain that he is extremely talkative, does not complete schoolwork, and frequently makes careless mistakes. They also complain that he frequently looks at other students or outside the window during the class and is often lost during the lessons. At home, he is very talkative and disorganized. When the pediatrician asks the boy his name, he replies promptly. He was born at full term by spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up-to-date on all vaccinations and has met all developmental milestones on time. A recent IQ test scored him at 95. His physical examination is completely normal. When he is asked to read from an age-appropriate children’s book, he reads it fluently and correctly.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble at school; I'm really talkative, don't finish my homework, and I often make careless mistakes.
How old are you? And are you a male or female?
I am a 9-year-old boy.
Have you had any similar issues in the past?
No, I did really well in kindergarten and first grade.
Is there a family history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or similar conditions?
I don't know, nobody has told me about that.
Do you have any other symptoms like impulsivity or difficulty staying still?
Yes, teachers say I don't stay on task and I often look around at others or outside instead of listening.
**Final Diagnosis:** Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
